Files Preliminary Prospectus for Proposed Initial Public OfferingBack to videoArticle contentExperienced Technology Executives Matt Proud and Avjit Kamboj with a Proven Ability to Build Scaled Tech Companies to Lead MAK‚Äôs Management TeamArticle contentTORONTO, Oct. 03, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) ‚ÄîMAK Acquisition Corp.(‚ÄúMAK‚Äù or the ‚ÄúCompany‚Äù), a newly formed special purpose acquisition company (‚ÄúSPAC‚Äù) established for the purpose of effecting a qualifying acquisition of one or more businesses, announced today that it has filed a¬†preliminary long form prospectus (the ‚ÄúPreliminary Prospectus‚Äù)¬†with the securities regulatory authorities in each of the provinces of Canada, except Quebec, in connection with a proposed initial public offering of¬†10,000,000 Class A restricted voting units of the Company¬†(the ‚ÄúClass A Units‚Äù) at a price of¬†US$10.00 per Class A Unit¬†for gross proceeds of¬†US$100,000,000 (the ‚ÄúOffering‚Äù).Article contentArticle contentEach Class A Unit is expected to consist of one Class A restricted voting share of the Company (a ‚ÄúClass A Share‚Äú) and¬†one-half¬†of a warrant (each whole warrant, a ‚ÄúWarrant‚Äù). Each whole Warrant will become exercisable commencing 65 days after the completion of the qualifying acquisition and will entitle the holder thereof to purchase one Class A Share at an exercise price of¬†US$11.50¬†for a period of¬†60 months¬†following completion of the Company‚Äôs qualifying acquisition, subject to customary adjustments and terms described in the Preliminary Prospectus. Each Class A Share is expected to convert into a subordinate voting share of the Company on completion of the qualifying acquisition.Article contentTop StoriesGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. Announces Acquisition of APSCO, LLCBack to videoArticle contentHOUSTON ‚ÄîDXP Enterprises, Inc. (NASDAQ: DXPE)today announced that it has completed the acquisition of APSCO, LLC (‚ÄúAPSCO‚Äù). Founded in 1986, APSCO is headquartered in Redmond, Washington servicing Alaska, Colorado, Hawaii, Idaho, Montana, Oregon, Washington, and Wyoming and surrounding markets.Article contentArticle contentAPSCO is a leading manufacturer‚Äôs representative of pumps, controls and process equipment focused on serving the water and wastewater industry. DXP funded the acquisition with cash from the balance sheet.Article contentTop StoriesGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Top Stories will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters?Browse here.Article content‚ÄúWe are pleased to announce the acquisition of APSCO. APSCO adds another great company to our water and wastewater platform. APSCO will enhance our product and aftermarket and service capabilities, along with furthering our efforts to grow our DXP Water platform,‚Äù commented David Little, Chairman, and Chief Executive Officer of DXP.Article contentThe signing of the definitive agreement occurred on October 1, 2025. Sales and adjusted EBITDA for APSCO for the last twelve months ending July 31, 2025, were approximately $12.9 million and $1.5 million, respectively. Adjusted EBITDA was calculated as income before tax, plus interest, plus depreciation and amortization, plus non-recurring items less go-forward selling costs.Article contentKent Yee, Chief Financial Officer, stated, ‚ÄúWe are very excited to have APSCO as a part of DXP. We are excited to welcome APSCO‚Äôs talented and hardworking employees to the DXP team. We continue to execute on our strategy of making acquisitions in markets and business models where we can continue to

title: Gold set for seventh weekly gain as U.S. shutdown clouds rate path
summary: Bullion held above US$3,880 an ounce, less than US$20 from a record reached on Thursday
content: Share this Story :Gold set for seventh weekly gain as U.S. shutdown clouds rate pathCopy LinkEmailXRedditPinterestLinkedInTumblrGold set for seventh weekly gain as U.S. shutdown clouds rate pathBullion held above US$3,880 an ounce, less than US$20 from a record reached on ThursdayAuthor of the article:Bloomberg NewsSybilla Gross and Yvonne Yue LiPublished Oct 03, 20251 minute readJoin the conversationYou can save this article by registering for freehere. Orsign-inif you have an account.One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on April 17, 2025.Photo by Brendon Thorne/BloombergArticle contentGold rose on Friday and headed for a seventh weekly advance as the U.S. government shutdown added another layer of uncertainty for investors seeking signals on theUnited States Federal Reserve‚Äôs monetary-easing path.THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR SUBSCRIBERS ONLYSubscribe now to read the latest news in your city and across Canada.Exclusive articles from Barbara Shecter, Joe O'Connor, Gabriel authorsSign In or Create an AccountEmail AddressContinueorView more offersArticle contentBullionheld above US$3,880 an ounce, less than US$20 from a record reached on Thursday. The torrid pace of the advance has left gold vulnerable to pullbacks, with technical indicators showing it‚Äôs been trading in overbought territory for the past month.Article contentWe apologize, but this video has failed to load.Try refreshing your browser, ortap here to see other videos from our team.Gold set for seventh weekly gain as U.S. shutdown clouds rate pathBack to videoWe apologize, but this video has failed to load.Try refreshing your browser, ortap here to see other videos from our team.Play VideoArticle contentArticle contentWith the U.S. shutdown delaying Friday‚Äôs government payroll report, investors have become reliant on private data for crucial clues about an already murky economic outlook. The blackout will also make it harder for central bankers to interpret the economy‚Äôs direction, Fed Bank of Chicago President Austan Goolsbee said this week. Money markets are still almost fully pricing a quarter-point cut at the end of the month, and are widely expecting another in December. Lower borrowing costs tend to benefit non-yielding precious metals.Article contentPosthasteBreaking business news, incisive views, must-reads and market signals. Weekdays by 9 a.m.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Posthaste will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters?Browse here.Article contentMeanwhile, the Institute for Supply Management‚Äôs index of services showed the U.S. service sector stalled in September as business activity shrank for the first time since the pandemic and orders barely expanded.Article contentArticle contentGold has soared about 48 per cent this year in a rally that‚Äôs seen successive all-time highs, with prices now on track for the biggest annual gain since 1979. The precious metal has been supported by central-bank buying and increasing holdings in gold-backed exchange-traded funds, as the Fed resumed interest-rate cuts.Article contentSpot gold traded up ¬†0.7 per

title: 3M Weighs Multibillion-Dollar Carve-Out in Industrials Arm
summary: 3M Co. is considering selling billions of dollars of assets from its industrials operations as it looks to carve out low-growth businesses, according to people familiar with the matter.
content: IndustriesConsumer3M Weighs Multibillion-Dollar Carve-Out in Industrials ArmFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftExpandThe 3M Co. Cottage Grove Center in Cottage Grove, Minnesota.Photographer: Daniel Acker/BloombergFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftGift this articleContact us:Provide news feedback or report an errorConfidential tip?Send a tip to our reportersSite feedback:Take our SurveyNew WindowFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftByDavid Carnevali,Kiel Porter, andRyan GouldOctober 3, 2025 at 6:12 PM UTCBookmarkSave3M Co.is considering selling billions of dollars of assets from its industrials operations as it looks to carve out low-growth businesses, according to people familiar with the matter.The conglomerate has been speaking withGoldman Sachs Group Inc.as it reviews potential divestments, said the people, who asked not to be identified because they weren‚Äôt authorized to speak publicly.

title: Howard Levitt: Why working notice is employment law‚Äôs most effective and underused tool, part two
summary: Employers save money, avoid the 'severance lottery' culture and sometimes even get a redemption story along the way
content: Share this Story :Howard Levitt: Why working notice is employment law's most effective and underused tool, part twoCopy LinkEmailXRedditPinterestLinkedInTumblrHoward Levitt: Why working notice is employment law's most effective and underused tool, part twoEmployers save money, avoid the 'severance lottery' culture and sometimes even get a redemption story along the wayAuthor of the article:ByHoward LevittPublished Oct 03, 20253 minute readJoin the conversationYou can save this article by registering for freehere. Orsign-inif you have an account.Employers who embrace working notice will save themselves considerable monies, writes Howard Levitt.Photo by Getty Images/iStockphotoArticle contentThree weeks ago in this space, I argued that working notice ‚Äî telling an employee their job will end after a defined period ‚Äî is the most underused tool in Canadianemployment law.THIS CONTENT IS RESERVED FOR SUBSCRIBERS ONLYSubscribe now to read the latest news in your city and across Canada.Exclusive articles from Barbara Shecter, Joe O'Connor, Gabriel Friedman, and others.Daily content from Financial business publication.Unlimited online access to read articles from Financial Post, National Post and 15 news sites across Canada with one account.National Post ePaper, an electronic replica of the print edition to view on any device, share and comment on.Daily puzzles, including the New York Times Crossword.REGISTER / SIGN IN TO UNLOCK MORE ARTICLESCreate an account or sign in to continue with your reading experience.Access articles from across Canada with one account.Share your thoughts and join the conversation in the comments.Enjoy additional articles per month.Get email updates from your favourite authors.THIS ARTICLE IS FREE TO READ REGISTER TO UNLOCK.Create an account or sign in to continue with your reading experience.Access articles from across Canada with one accountShare your thoughts and join the conversation in the commentsEnjoy additional articles per monthGet email updates from your favourite authorsSign In or Create an AccountEmail AddressContinueorView more offersArticle contentEmployers wrote me by the dozens to say it was a revelation. Some were astonished they had never considered it. Others said they had, but admitted they lacked the courage to try it.Article contentWe apologize, but this video has failed to load.Try refreshing your browser, ortap here to see other videos from our team.Howard Levitt: Why working notice is employment law's most effective and underused tool, part twoBack to videoWe apologize, but this video has failed to load.Try refreshing your browser, ortap here to see other videos from our team.Play VideoArticle contentSo, let‚Äôs continue the conversation.Article contentArticle contentWorking notice is not only legally sound; it is (counterintuitively) more humane than firing. It spares employees the humiliation of the sudden escort out the door and gives them time to plan their next step. Employers save money, avoid the ‚Äúseverance lottery‚Äù culture (more on this below) and sometimes even get a redemption story along the way.Article contentWorkFP Work touches on HR strategy, labour economics, office culture, technology and more.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Work will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters?Browse here.Article contentHere are the lessons every employer should learn.Article contentThe classic firing ends with a banker‚Äôs box and the dreaded ‚Äúwalk of shame.‚Äù Working notice eliminates that. The employee keeps their salary, benefits and stature while quietly preparing their next move. They leave on their own feet, not under guard. Dignity is a valuable thing.Article contentWe all know employees who say, ‚ÄúI hate this job but I‚Äôm hanging on until they fire me so I can get my package.‚ÄùArticle contentThat mindset corrodes morale. When companies establish a reputation for working notice, that culture dies overnight. No one lingers hoping for a severance jackpot because they know it isn‚Äôt coming.Article contentThe biggest mistake managers make is waiting until the employee‚Äôs frustration boils over.

title: Fire Shuts Chevron Refinery Units Near LA as Fuel Crunch Looms
summary: Chevron Corp.‚Äôs El Segundo refinery in Los Angeles County has shut multiple units as it continues battling a fire that broke out last night, the latest threat to fuel supplies in a state that‚Äôs already bracing for shortfalls.
content: Share this Story :Fire Shuts Chevron Refinery Units Near LA as Fuel Crunch LoomsCopy LinkEmailXRedditLinkedInTumblrFire Shuts Chevron Refinery Units Near LA as Fuel Crunch LoomsChevron Corp.‚Äôs El Segundo refinery in Los Angeles County has shut multiple units as it continues battling a fire that broke out last night, the latest threat to fuel supplies in a state that‚Äôs already bracing for shortfalls.Author of the article:Bloomberg NewsBarbara Powell, Devika Krishna Kumar and Yongchang ChinPublished Oct 03, 20252 minute readJoin the conversationYou can save this article by registering for freehere. videos from our team.Fire Shuts Chevron Refinery Units Near LA as Fuel Crunch LoomsBack to videoArticle content‚ÄúThe fire originated at a process unit at the southeast corner of the refinery,‚Äù said Becky Robinson, a spokesperson for the city of El Segundo. ‚ÄúThe fire is contained, but fire crews continue to work to fully extinguish the incident.‚ÄùArticle contentArticle contentThe fire was isolated and there were no injuries, a representative for Chevron said in a statement. All refinery personnel and contractors have been accounted for, the spokesperson said.Article contentTop StoriesGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Top Stories will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters?Browse here.Article contentUnits shut Thursday night include the 60,000 barrel-a-day catalytic reformer, the 45,000 barrel-a-day hydrocracker, the 73,000 barrel-a-day fluid catalytic cracker and two hydrogen plants, according to Wood Mackenzie.Article contentArticle contentThe fire appears to have begun at the convection section of a furnace that is part of the Hydrocracker/ISOMAX complex, said Randy Hurburun, head of refining at energy consultancy Energy Aspects. That complex makes distillates, including diesel and jet fuel.Article contentThe entire hydrocracker section will likely have to be shut for assessment and repair, and crude rates will probably be slowed to limit feedstock output that would have gone to the hydrocracker, Hurburun said.Article contentChevron said there were no evacuations for nearby residents and emissions from the refinery haven‚Äôt exceeded permitted levels, based on the facility‚Äôs monitoring system.Article contentThis week, Phillips 66 said its L

title: Taylor Swift prepares to take a ‚ÄòShowgirl‚Äô-themed victory lap as she eyes a $35 million haul and a second box-office number 1
summary: "The Life of a Showgirl," Swift's new album, is being accompanied by a three-day film event: "The Official Release Party of a Showgirl.‚Äù
content: Success¬∑MusicTaylor Swift prepares to take a ‚ÄòShowgirl‚Äô-themed victory lap as she eyes a $35 million haul and a second box-office number 1ByNick LichtenbergByNick LichtenbergFortune Intelligence EditorNick LichtenbergFortune Intelligence EditorNick Lichtenberg is business editor and was formerlyFortune's executive editor of global news.SEE FULL BIOTaylor Swift arrives for the 67th Annual Grammy Awards at the Crypto.com Arena in Los Angeles on February 2, 2025.ROBYN BECK/AFP via Getty ImagesTaylor Swift is preparing to take a cinematic victory lap, as box-office analysts project her special cinematic event,The Official Release Party of a Showgirlrunning from Oct. 3-5, to dominate this weekend to accompany her new album,The Life of a Showgirl. The movie, announced two weeks ago and minimally promoted since, is tracking at between $35 million to $40 million,Varietyreported, noting it would be Swift‚Äôs second chart-topping opening in as many years.The new theatrical venture, designed as part-album launch, part-experiential event, signals a typically Swiftian and extraordinary fusion of fandom and business acumen, arriving at the perfect moment to energize theaters nationwide afteranother lackluster post-pandemic year of returns. Neither a standard biopic nor a concert documentary, the film is an 89-minute communal celebration featuring exclusive music videos and candid behind-the-scenes content documenting the making of Swift‚Äôs 12th album.‚ÄúI hereby invite you to a *dazzling* soir√©e, The Official Release Party of a Showgirl: Oct 3 ‚Äì Oct 5 only in cinemas,‚Äù Swiftwrote across social media Sept. 19.Tickets are priced at $12, a nod to her affinity for numerology, balancing accessibility and premium experience. This modest price, while above national averages, remains lower than what fans would expect at major theater chains in cities such as New York and Los Angeles.Boxoffice joustingBox office analysts agreeShowgirlis on track to outpace all rivals this weekend. Its nearest competitor, Dwayne Johnson‚Äôs prestige dramaThe Smashing Machine, is expected to open with only $8 million to $15 million‚Äîa fraction of Swift‚Äôs predicted debut. Meanwhile, major releases likeLeonardoDiCaprio‚Äôs action thrillerOne Battle After Anotherare also trailing by significant margins.The community response has been overwhelming, as exhibitors clear their schedules to accommodate the influx of Swift fans. This kind of turnout is reminiscent of her blockbuster2023 Taylor Swift: The Eras Tourfilm, which posted a $93 million opening and went on to break concert movie records worldwide. WhileShowgirlisn‚Äôt likely to repeat those heights due to its specialist focus and shorter run, its impact is still considerable for the current October box office.Fan experience and cultural momentSwift‚Äôs latest effort isn‚Äôt just about racking up ticket sales‚Äîit‚Äôs about creating a one-of-a-kind, communal experience for fans. The event doubles as an album release party and movie screening, integrating the debut of singles like ‚ÄúThe Fate of Ophelia‚Äù with documentary-style vignettes and stories behind the music. Designed to be interactive, theShowgirlrelease is a testament to Swift‚Äôs ability to engage fandom and transform ordinary weekends at the multiplex into landmark pop-culture moments.Swift‚Äôs current success owes much to her disciplined business strategy‚Äîwhich aHarvard Business Reviewanalysis described in 2024 as a ‚Äúproductive paranoia‚Äù that continually prompts her to pivot before competitors catch up. Rather than sticking to a single genre or promotional cycle, Swift evolves her content volume and style to fit streaming algorithms while manufacturing major moments with premium events, such as exclusive tours and movie tie-ins. Special editions, collectible releases, and layered ‚Äúwindows‚Äù for product drops (like the limited theatrical run forShowgirl) are all textbook examples of Swift‚Äôs playbook: multiplying demand, ensuring ownership, and extracting maximum value from her audience.The billion-dollar empireBloombergestimates Swift‚Äôs net worth at $1.6 billion, a remarkable figure for someone who‚Äôs grown her wealth primarily via music and performance rather than secondary ventures. Her approach combines catalog ownership, touring, streaming, and direct sales, creating a conglomerate effect with herself as the charismatic CEO and her superfans as loyal, repeat customers.One of Swift‚Äôs core strengths is turning every major drop into a tightly orchestrated event, where fans become true stakeholders in her success.Showgirlencourages participation, not just attendance‚Äîintegrating live album debuts, video launches, and social media-driven engagement. This continuous conversation, heightened by agile promo tactics and surprise announcements, is central to Swift‚Äôs stranglehold on cultural capital.Swift‚Äôs path offers valuable lessons for business leaders and cultural innovators: preemptive pivots, treating product launches as time-limited spectacles, maximizing direct owne

title: Palantir Rebuts Claims of Security Flaws After Stock Falls
summary: Palantir Technologies Inc.‚Äôs stock fell more than 8% on Friday following a report that its battlefield communications system, along with that of defense tech firm Anduril Industries Inc., was seriously flawed — a claim both companies said was out of date and inaccurate.
content: TechnologyPalantir Rebuts Claims of Security Flaws After Stock FallsFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftExpandPhotographer: Michael Nagle/BloombergFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftGift this articleContact us:Provide news feedback or report an errorConfidential tip?Send a tip to our reportersSite feedback:Take our SurveyNew WindowFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftByLizette ChapmanandFelice MaranzOctober 3, 2025 at 5:50 PM UTCBookmarkSavePalantir Technologies Inc.‚Äôs stock fell more than 8% on Friday following a report that its battlefield communications system, along with that of defense tech firmAnduril Industries Inc., was seriously flawed ‚Äî a claim both companies said was out of date and inaccurate.In a statement Friday, Palantir said that issues in the report,published by Reuters, had already been addressed. The report centered on a September Army memo expressing concerns over Anduril‚Äôs NGC2 prototype system, which stands for Next Generation Command and Control, and includes subcontractors Palantir andMicrosoft Corp. The Armyhas saidthe problems with the system were ‚Äúmitigated immediately,‚Äù Palantir said, adding, ‚ÄúNo vulnerabilities were found in the Palantir platform.‚Äù

title: Regulators approve disputed $6.2B takeover of Minnesota Power by investment group
summary: MINNEAPOLIS (AP) — Minnesota regulators voted unanimously Friday to approve an investment group’s takeover of a power company over the objections of the state attorney general, big industrial electricity buyers and consumer advocates. In voting for the takeover of Duluth-based Minnesota, the five members of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission said they believe the conditions […]

AddressContinueorView more offersArticle contentIn voting for the takeover of Duluth-based Minnesota, the five members of the Minnesota Public Utilities Commission said they believe the conditions imposed on the deal will protect the public interest and shield customers from rate increases. Opponents warned that the private equity group is only interested in squeezing bigger profits from regular ratepayers.Article contentWe apologize, but this video has failed to load.Try refreshing your browser, ortap here to see other videos from our team.Regulators approve disputed $6.2B takeover of Minnesota Power by investment groupBack to videoArticle contentArticle contentThe approval came as electricity bills are rising fast across the U.S., and growing evidence suggests the bills of some residential customers are increasing to subsidize the rapid build-out of power plants and power lines to supply the gargantuan energy needs of Big Tech‚Äôs data centers and the boom in artificial intelligence.Article contentTop StoriesGet the latest headlines, breaking news and columns.There was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpBy signing up you consent to receive the above newsletter from Postmedia Network Inc.Thanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. If you don't see it, please check your junk folder.The next issue of Top Stories will soon be in your inbox.We encountered an issue signing you up. Please try againInterested in more newsletters?Browse here.Article contentRaising the stakes is the potential that Google could build a data center in Minnesota Power‚Äôs territory in the northern part of the state, a lucrative prospect for the utility‚Äôs owner.Article contentOpponents also expressed fear that the sale would encourage more such deals across the U.S.Article contentUnder the planned buyout, a BlackRock subsidiary and the Canada Pension Plan Investment Board will take over the publicly traded company Allete, parent of Minnesota Power, which provides power to 150,000 customers and owns a variety of power sources, including coal, gas, wind and solar.Article contentThe buyout price is $6.2 billion, including $67 a share for stockholders at a 19% premium, and assuming $2.3 billion in debt. In its petition, Allete told regulators that Minnesota Power‚Äôs operations, strategy and values wouldn‚Äôt change under BlackRock and that the deal‚Äôs cost wouldn‚Äôt affect electric rates.Article contentA

title: Macron Blames Russia for Death of a French Journalist in Ukraine
summary: President Emmanuel Macron blamed Russia for the death on Friday of a French photojournalist, Antoni Lallican, in a drone attack while on assignment in Ukraine.
content: PoliticsEuropeMacron Blames Russia for Death of a French Journalist in UkraineFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftExpandFrance's president¬†Emmanuel MacronPhotographer: Krisztian Bocsi/BloombergFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftGift this articleContact us:Provide news feedback or report an errorConfidential tip?Send a tip to our reportersSite feedback:Take our SurveyNew WindowFacebookXLinkedInEmailLinkGiftByVidya N RootOctober 3, 2025 at 5:49 PM UTCBookmarkSavePresidentEmmanuel Macronblamed Russia for the death on Friday of a French photojournalist, Antoni Lallican, in a drone attack while on assignment in Ukraine.‚ÄúI learned with deep sadness of his death, a victim of a Russian drone attack,‚Äù the French president said in a post on X.
